nexttext: We used the association rule for extracting social network from online database such as DBLP and for enhancing the superficial method, but this approach depend on the structure of DBLP web page. In previous research, association rule can be generally defined as $b_1,\dots,b_{|B|-1} \Rightarrow b_{|B|}$, where $X = \{b_1,\dots,b_{|B|-1|}\}$, and $Y = \{a_{|B|}\}$. {array}" display="block"><mtable columnspacing="5pt" displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="right"><mrow><mrow><mi>T</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>F</mi></mrow><mo>.</mo><mrow><mi>I</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>D</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>F</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>w</mi></mrow></mrow></mtd><mtd columnalign="center"><mo>=</mo></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>f</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>w</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>⋅</mo><mi>i</mi></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>f</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>w</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd/><mtd columnalign="center"><mo>=</mo></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mo maxsize="160%" minsize="160%">(</mo><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>j</mi><mo>∈</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">{</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">…</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>N</mi><mo stretchy="false">}</mo></mrow></mrow></munder><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>∈</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">{</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">…</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>m</mi><mo stretchy="false">}</mo></mrow></mrow></munder><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mi>n</mi></mfrac></mrow></mrow><mo maxsize="160%" minsize="160%">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mi>log</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mfrac><mi>N</mi><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>f</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>w</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></math>

nexttext:
\section{Extraction and Information Retrieval}
First step for building any network is to determine nodes \cite{lin1999,newman2003}. Discretely, a node $v \in V$ in a graph $G$, is a representation of any object in a network, i.e. $V = \{v_i|i = 1,\dots,n\}$, $V \ne\emptyset$. The nodes in a social network refer to actor names such as authors, recipients, researchers, artists. Therefore, the first task of extracting social network, $\xi$, is to identify the actors. This can be achieved by providing a list of names as seeds in order to extract other names, recognize and disambiguate them \cite{balog2009,cullota2004}. The actors play some role in a social based on their background, and they have some characteristics as attributes. Formally, such attributes of actors we define as $Z = \{z_j|j=1,\dots,m\}$ which are attributes / characteristics of entities whereby a pair of $\langle A,Z\rangle$ is the instance of actors, where $Z_i$ are subsets of $Z$, $Z_i$ are subsets of attributes of each entity $a_i$, i.e. $\langle a_i,Z_i\rangle$, $i = 1,\dots,n$, or simply denotes a set of attributes of entity a as $Z_a$.

We developed an approach to extracting keywords from web snippets for disambiguating names in social networks. The methods for using keyword in query are \cite{mika2007}:

\begin{tabular}{rcl}
noK	&:& A name pair  used as query without relation keywords.\cr
K1  	&:& A name pair and top-weighted relation keyword used as a query.\cr
K2  	&:& A name pair and second-weighted relation keyword used \cr
        & & as a query.\cr
K1+K2 	&:& A name pair and top-weighted strongest relation keyword.\cr
\end{tabular}

\noindent
By considering a set of snippets $L$, each contains a reference to a person. Let $P = \{P_1,\dots,P_{|P|}\}$ be a partition of $\xi$ and $\zeta$ into references to the same person, so for example $P_i = \{S_1, S_4, S_5, S_9\}$ might be a set of references to "Abdul Razak Hamdan" the information technology professor. We produce the current context for each actor where keywords have two vector, $\nu$ and $\upsilon$: first vector we define based on TF.IDF and second vector we generate from hit count, and then we define delta $\delta$ as distance of two vector. We use delta to select keyword from each classes of candidates that grouped by tree of network semantic of words \cite{nasution2010a}.  

Let $C = \{C_1,\dots,C_{|C|}\}$ be a collection of disjoint subset of $L$ created by algorithm and manually validated such that each $S$ has an identifier, i.e. URL address. Then, we denote $L_C$ as references that  be the clusters based on collection. Based on measure were introduced, we define an notation of recall $Rec()$ as follows
prevtext: where $n$ is the number of words in a document, $m$ is the number of word $w$ in document $j$, $N$ is the total number of documents, and $df(w)$ is the number of documents containing the word $w$. The normalization of TF.IDF, is defined as

\section{Extraction and Information Retrieval}
First step for building any network is to determine nodes \cite{lin1999,newman2003}. Discretely, a node $v \in V$ in a graph $G$, is a representation of any object in a network, i.e. $V = \{v_i|i = 1,\dots,n\}$, $V \ne\emptyset$. The nodes in a social network refer to actor names such as authors, recipients, researchers, artists. Therefore, the first task of extracting social network, $\xi$, is to identify the actors. This can be achieved by providing a list of names as seeds in order to extract other names, recognize and disambiguate them \cite{balog2009,cullota2004}. The actors play some role in a social based on their background, and they have some characteristics as attributes. Formally, such attributes of actors we define as $Z = \{z_j|j=1,\dots,m\}$ which are attributes / characteristics of entities whereby a pair of $\langle A,Z\rangle$ is the instance of actors, where $Z_i$ are subsets of $Z$, $Z_i$ are subsets of attributes of each entity $a_i$, i.e. $\langle a_i,Z_i\rangle$, $i = 1,\dots,n$, or simply denotes a set of attributes of entity a as $Z_a$.

We developed an approach to extracting keywords from web snippets for disambiguating names in social networks. The methods for using keyword in query are \cite{mika2007}:

\begin{tabular}{rcl}
noK	&:& A name pair  used as query without relation keywords.\cr
K1  	&:& A name pair and top-weighted relation keyword used as a query.\cr
K2  	&:& A name pair and second-weighted relation keyword used \cr
        & & as a query.\cr
K1+K2 	&:& A name pair and top-weighted strongest relation keyword.\cr
\end{tabular}

\noindent
By considering a set of snippets $L$, each contains a reference to a person. Let $P = \{P_1,\dots,P_{|P|}\}$ be a partition of $\xi$ and $\zeta$ into references to the same person, so for example $P_i = \{S_1, S_4, S_5, S_9\}$ might be a set of references to "Abdul Razak Hamdan" the information technology professor. We produce the current context for each actor where keywords have two vector, $\nu$ and $\upsilon$: first vector we define based on TF.IDF and second vector we generate from hit count, and then we define delta $\delta$ as distance of two vector. We use delta to select keyword from each classes of candidates that grouped by tree of network semantic of words \cite{nasution2010a}.  

Let $C = \{C_1,\dots,C_{|C|}\}$ be a collection of disjoint subset of $L$ created by algorithm and manually validated such that each $S$ has an identifier, i.e. URL address. Then, we denote $L_C$ as references that  be the clusters based on collection. Based on measure were introduced, we define an notation of recall $Rec()$ as follows
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E6.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="Rec(S_{i})=\frac{|\{S\in P(S_{i}):C(S)=C(S_{i})\}|}{|\{S\in P(S_{i})\}|}" display="block"><mrow><mrow><mi>R</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>e</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>S</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">{</mo><mrow><mi>S</mi><mo>∈</mo><mrow><mi>P</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>S</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>:</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>C</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>S</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mi>C</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>S</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">}</mo></mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">{</mo><mi>S</mi><mo>∈</mo><mi>P</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>S</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo stretchy="false">}</mo></mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow></mfrac></mrow></math>

nexttext: where $P(S_i)$ as a set $P_i$ containing reference $S_i$ and $C(S_i)$ to be the set $C_i$ containing $S_i$. Thus, the precision of a reference to "Abdul Razak Hamdan" is the fraction of references in the same cluster that are also to "Abdul Razak Hamdan". We obtain average of: recall (REC), precision (PREC), and F-measure for the clustering C as follows:
prevtext: and a notation of precision $Prec()$ as follows
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E7.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="Prec(S_{i})=\frac{|\{S\in C(S_{i}):P(S)=P(S_{i})\}|}{|\{S\in C(S_{i})\}|}" display="block"><mrow><mrow><mi>P</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>r</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>e</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>S</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">{</mo><mrow><mi>S</mi><mo>∈</mo><mrow><mi>C</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>S</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>:</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>P</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>S</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mi>P</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>S</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">}</mo></mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">{</mo><mi>S</mi><mo>∈</mo><mi>C</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>S</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo stretchy="false">}</mo></mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow></mfrac></mrow></math>

prevtext: where $P(S_i)$ as a set $P_i$ containing reference $S_i$ and $C(S_i)$ to be the set $C_i$ containing $S_i$. Thus, the precision of a reference to "Abdul Razak Hamdan" is the fraction of references in the same cluster that are also to "Abdul Razak Hamdan". We obtain average of: recall (REC), precision (PREC), and F-measure for the clustering C as follows:
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E8.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="REC=\frac{\sum_{S\in L_{C}}Rec(S)}{|L_{C}|}" display="block"><mrow><mrow><mi>R</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>E</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>C</mi></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><msub><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>S</mi><mo>∈</mo><msub><mi>L</mi><mi>C</mi></msub></mrow></msub><mrow><mi>R</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>e</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>S</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><msub><mi>L</mi><mi>C</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow></mfrac></mrow></math>

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E9.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="PREC=\frac{\sum_{S\in L_{C}}Prec(S)}{|L_{C}|}" display="block"><mrow><mrow><mi>P</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>R</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>E</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>C</mi></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><msub><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>S</mi><mo>∈</mo><msub><mi>L</mi><mi>C</mi></msub></mrow></msub><mrow><mi>P</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>r</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>e</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>S</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><msub><mi>L</mi><mi>C</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow></mfrac></mrow></math>

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex4.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="F_{measure}=\frac{2(|E_{1}\cap E_{2}|)^{2}}{|E_{1}|\cdot|E_{1}\cap E_{2}|+|E_{%
2}|\cdot|E_{1}\cap E_{2}|}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>F</mi><mrow><mi>m</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>e</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>u</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>r</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>e</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mrow><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>∩</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow><mo>⋅</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mrow><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>∩</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow><mo>⋅</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mrow><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>∩</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>
